posts.raw_content:
Tax Hikes Trigger Exodus of Businesses and Wealthy Residents
The $6B revenue plan (corporate tax to 11.5%, millionaire's tax) could raise effective rates to 15%+ with state/federal layers, per NY Post analysis—pushing firms like Goldman Sachs (already eyeing Florida) to flee, costing 100K+ jobs. Critics like the Cato Institute call it "punitive socialism" that ignores NYC's 40% reliance on finance/tech; expect a "brain drain" as billionaires bolt, slashing the $100B+ tax base and worsening the deficit to $15B by 2028. Early X buzz labels it "tax-and-spend ruin."
Rent Controls and Housing Mandates Worsen Shortages
Freezing rents (covering 1M+ units) and forcing 200K "affordable" builds sound compassionate but, per economists, distort markets: Landlords defer maintenance, black markets thrive, and supply craters (as seen in SF's 30% vacancy drop post-controls). Seizing properties risks lawsuits clogging courts for years, while union-only builds inflate costs 20-30%—turning NYC into a "ghost town of decaying tenements" as middle-class families decamp to Texas suburbs.
City-Run Groceries and Freebies Breed Inefficiency and Dependency
Public grocery stores (partnering with neighborhoods) aim to undercut prices but mirror flops like Soviet co-ops or de Blasio's IDNYC waste—bureaucratic bloat could cost $500M/year in subsidies, with spoilage and favoritism scandals. Bodega owners and Gristedes' John Catsimatidis decry it as "government takeover" killing 5,000 small businesses. Pair with free childcare ($2B hit) and buses ($1B), and you get "welfare bloat" that addicts residents to handouts while services crumble—think longer ER waits as taxes fund "feel-good" pilots over infrastructure.
"Soft-on-Crime" Safety Shifts Fuel Chaos
The Community Safety Dept. prioritizes outreach over cops, echoing 2020's "defund" era when murders spiked 40%. With subway teams and "interrupters" (unarmed civilians), critics fear a 20% crime uptick as perps game the system—subways become "no-go zones," tourism tanks (NYC's $70B lifeline), and Trump-era feds withhold aid, labeling it a "sanctuary for criminals."
Broader "Socialist" Overreach Stifles Innovation
Green Schools and $30 min. wage could create jobs short-term but hike tuition/labor costs, pricing out private schools and eateries (50K at risk). Overall, Mamdani's "seize the means" vibe (per X critics) challenges private property, inviting federal clashes under Trump 2.0—cue withheld HUD funds, turning NYC into a "blue-state basket case."

 Mamdani's win isn't a fresh start but a fast-track to bankruptcy like Detroit's 2013 woes—exacerbated by his inexperience (no exec role) and DSA ties.
